title.narrative: Beyond the Grid Fund for Africa
Beyond the Grid Fund for Africa

description.narrative:
Beyond the Grid Fund for Africa (BGFA) är ett flerårigt program som syftar till att öka tillgången till energi, förbättra fattiga människors utkomstmöjligheter och katalysera ekonomisk aktivitet i landsbygdsområden och slumområden i sex länder - Burkina Faso, Liberia, Mozambique, Zambia, Uganda och Demokratiska Republiken Kongo. Det är en uppskalning och utvidgning av ett program som prövats i Zambia med goda resultat. BGFA har som mål att leverera billiga och tillförlitliga förnybara energitjänster till mellan fem och femton miljoner människor, på landsbygden och i peri-urbana områden som inte täcks av nationella elnät. BGFA ska skynda på marknadstillträde och marknadsutveckling inom ett nytt segment av utvecklingsfrämjande energitjänster som riktar sig till fattiga konsumenter vilka redan idag lägger en mycket stor del av den disponibla inkomsten på undermåliga former av energi. BGFA har som övergripande mål att bidra till uppfyllandet av det globala hållbarhetsmålet nr 7 - att säkerställa att alla har tillgång till tillförlitlig, hållbar och modern energi till en överkomlig kostnad.
BGFA använder en ny och innovativ modell för resultatbaserad offentlig upphandling (Social Impact Procurement) som mobiliserar privata resurser för att bidra till att lösa utvecklingsutmaningar i stor skala. Samtidigt ska BGFA förbättra förutsättningarna för en marknad för hållbara energitjänster, genom att bygga kapacitet och kunskap hos olika aktörer, bidra till samordning om frågorna samt samla in, analysera och följa upp data från energibolag och deras kunder (Platforms for Market Change). BGFA lägger stor vikt vid att säkra additionell finansiering från exempelvis investerare, banker och kreditinstitut. En uppskattning baserad på resultaten i Zambia är att det svenska bidraget katalyserar 3-4 gånger så mycket i privat kapital. BGFA innebär stöd till företag för att täcka risker i samband med uppskalning och växande. Huvuddelen av företagens finansiering kommer från verksamheten - att leverera energitjänster av hög kvalitet till överkomliga kostnader förmänniskor med små och oregelbundna inkomster.
BGFA ska genomföras av Nordiska Miljöfinansieringsbolaget (NEFCO), en internationell finansieringsinstitution specialiserad på miljöinvesteringar och ägd av de nordiska länderna. NEFCO tillhandahåller resultatbaserad finansiering för miljöinvesteringar, förnybar energi och energieffektivisering. BGFA kommer genomföras av NEFCO i samarbete med Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Partnership (REEEP), en österrikisk internationell organisation som fokuserar på att skynda på marknadsutveckling för förnybar energi och energieffektivisering.

The Beyond the Grid Fund for Africa (BGFA) is a planned expansion and scale up of an innovative, results-based initiative incentivising private sector to provide affordable, efficient, high quality, renewable energy services to underserved people in off-grid rural and peri-urban areas that builds on experience of the Beyond the Grid Fund for Zambia. Sida's proposed support to BGFA includes, Burkina Faso, Liberia, Mozambique, Zambia, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo. BGFA aims to reach 5-15 million people with clean, renewable and reliable energy services. BGFA is designed to stimulate and accelerate the emergence of new business models for provision of affordable energy access at scale whilst demonstrating sustainability over time. The BGFA particularly supports the objectives of the Sustainable Development Goal 7 (SDG 7), which aims to ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy access for all by 2030.
BGFA is a tailored, results-based incentive scheme for private sector early movers in risky frontier markets that are targeting underserved market segments. BGFA uses a tailored tender process (Social Impact Procurement) to “procure” modern energy services that are currently not sufficiently profitable for purely commercial activity. BGFA works in parallel to improve market ecosystem conditions, utilising a combination of capacity building and technical assistance, stakeholder outreach and market intelligence development, in a “Platform for Change” approach. In addition, BGFA combines detailed market analysis with data and information on from a monitoring and evaluation framework, yielding valuable insights and metrics on “frontier” markets and end-customer preferences. This information is utilised to help market stakeholders increase quality of energy services delivered to end customers, and improve investment and other development-related decision making (e.g. from banks, credit institutions and other investors) and delivered to the market via the Platform for Change. Based on previous results in Zambia, BGFA is expected to mobilise private resources of around 3-4 times the Swedish support. The Swedish support is designed to cover part of the risk margin for scaling and growing sustainable businesses. The main share of the companies financing will come from their operations - delivery of high quality energy services at affordable costs to consumers at the bottom of the pyramid.
The BGFA will be managed by the Nordic Environment Finance Corporation (NEFCO), a Public Financial Institution, focused on environmental investments, established by the Nordic Governments in 1990. NEFCO provides results-based green financing. BGFA will be managed by NEFCO in partnership with the Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Partnership (REEEP), an Austria-based international multilateral partnership, working to accelerate market-based deployment of renewable energy and energy efficiency.

sector.narrative: Energy generation, renewable sources - multiple technologies

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
17.3 - Mobilisera additionella finansiella resurser till utvecklingsländerna från många olika källor.
17.3 - Mobilize additional financial resources for developing countries from multiple sources.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

description.narrative:
This conclusion on performance covers the period from June 2020 to June 2021, and is based on two semi-annual reports, documentation and dialogue during Steering Committee meetings as well as Sidas overall experience of BGFA.
Zambia
For Burkina Faso, Liberia, Uganda and Mozambique there are no results in terms of verified connections as of yet. However, Zambia has been included under BFGA following the previous work with Beyond the Grid Fund Zambia (BFGZ), and thus has an active portfolio consisting of four companies, of which two have strengthened their market penetration in Zambia whereas two entered the Zambian market for the first time.
At the time of contracting ESPs in June 2017, only 4,000 customers had been reached with PAYGO Solar Home Systems (SHS). As of June 2021, BGFZ has reached some 981 271 Zambian beneficiaries, 98% of the total target, having financed some 188 706 Energy Service Subscriptions (ESS). Out of these, 29% of primary customers are women. The target of reaching 1 million Zambians is expected to be reached in Q3 2021. The original target of 310 845 ESS was adjusted because of the Covid-19 pandemic to 268 939 (-13%). While BFGZ overperformed ESS targets in 2020, exceeding its December 2020 target by 20%, in June 2021 BGFZ has fallen short of its target by 12%. The companies have created 1845 jobs in total, of which 25% are hired employees whereas the remaining 75% are agents selling ESS on a commission basis.
A evaluation of BGFZ was carried out by 60 decibels (60dbs) during the first half year in 2021. The evaluation was designed to verify the results for the four ESPs financed under BGFZ and to get insights from the customer level, such as feedback, impact, satisfaction and experience. The method for the evaluation was to survey 554 people by telephone which was then complemented by 72 in-person surveys. Of the respondents, 76% had purchased a SHS, 17% had purchased a mini-grid and 7% a clean cooking solution.
Sida assesses that the study confirms a strong development impact of the contribution. The 60dbs study found that 85% of customers were accessing the service for the first time, 86% had no access to a good alternative, 83% saw their quality of life as "very much improved" and 58% of customers reached were peole living in poverty (below $3.10/day). While 60dbs assesses that BGFZ still under-serves people living in poverty to some extent, Sida assesses that 58% is a strong result for a market-based intervention. Split according to product, 100% of customers bought clean cooking for the first time, 96% bought mini-grids for the first time and 79% bought a SHS for the first time, giving an indication of the market penetration of the respective products. 9% of customers report using their product or service for productive uses.
36% of respondents reported challenges however, of which 63% were not resolved, which offered the ESPs key insights for improvements going forward. In terms of customer demographics, the report finds a wide degree of variability. 53% were located in rural areas, 38% in peri-urban towns and 9% in urban areas. The evaluation also showed that BGFZs EDISON monitoring and verification tool had a 97% accuracy in terms of total customer details.
In terms of capital mobilization, the portfolio has leveraged a total of 48,5 mUSD in total, of which 11,1 mUSD was leveraged since December 2020, which Sida assesses as a highly catalytic result, mobilizing capital above a 1:4 leverage ratio, and with ongoing negotiations for up to 1:8, where for every grant dollar, 8 dollars are leveraged from private debt providors and/or investors. Of the total leveraged financing 42% is equity, 23% is debt and 26% are grants. Sida assesses that 42% equity is a strong result confirming the financial viability of the companies in question and the RBF model as such, given that equity financing often is more difficult to access than debt.
The success has stirred the interest of the Zambian government, and the Rural Electrification Authority (REA) is now developing an RBF-programme to be funded with their own budget, reusing substantial parts of the procurement-, contracting- and Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) approach developed under BGFZ/BGFA. Sida, NEFCO and REEEP have engaged in meetings with REA and the World Bank on this and shared relevant documentatoin. As part of another contribution, Data 4 Development, funded under the Regional Strategy with sub-Saharan Africa, REEEP is adapting the EDISON MRV tool to the planned programme in Zambia and providing capacitty development support to REA.
Call for Proposals #1 - Burkina Faso, Liberia and Zambia.
In June 2020, the first Call for Proposals for BGFA was pre-announced, with pre-qualification guidelines published on September 15th, covering six funding lots in Burkina Faso, Liberia and Zambia for a total funding of some 30 mEUR. On October 30th, the call was closed, having received 84 applications. Successful applications were invited in December 2020 to submit full project proposals including business plans. The calls are split into two categories: Launch to Scale (LS) for early stage market actors, which are designed to mitigate risks in early stage markets for off-grid energy solutions using flexible financing, and Direct to Scale (DS) for market actors that are active in intermediate-advanced markets that are able to immediately and rapidly scale operations and delivery on a fixed "payment on result" basis. LS and DS have different criteria for payments.
- In Burkina Faso, BFGA launched one funding window (LS) of up to 6,7 mEUR, focused on standalone solar home systems (SHS), with the expected number of contracts being 3-4. A total of 10 projects applied; 7 passed and 3 were rejected.
-In Liberia, BGFA launched two funding windows (LS); one for standalone SHS of up to 4,2 mEUR; one for mini-/micro-grids of up tp 2,5 mEUR; expecting some 3-5 contracts in total. A total of 9 projects applied: 7 passed and 2 were rejected.
- In Zambia, BFGA launched three funding windows: one LS window for standalone SHS of up to 5,2 mEUR; one LS window for mini/micro-grids of up to 6,6mEUR; and one DS window for standalone SHS. A total of 20 projects applied, of which 16 passed and 4 were rejected
Of all the projects in the three countries, the 15 highest-ranking projects, corresponding to the available funding in each Lot, were passed to the in-depth due diligence review. The due diligence process was commenced by REEEP in June 2021.
Call for Proposals #2 - Mozambique
Mozambique was launched as a separate call for proposals on December 10th due to internal processes in Mozambique related to mini-grid regulations.
- BFGA launched a funding window exclusively for microgrids and complementary standalone solutions in 87 predetermined sites for a total of 6,7 mEUR. 17 applications were received, of which 7 passed the Evaluation Committee and which have been invited to submit a full proposal.
Call for Proposals #3 - Uganda
In Uganda, the prequalification for the third call of proposals was launched April 29th 2021, closing on June 22nd.
- BFGA launched three funding windows; one LS window for standalone SHS of up to 6,2 mEUR; one LS window for mini/micro-grids of up to 6,2 mEUR and one DS window for standalone SHS of up to 8,3 mEUR. 19 of 30 applications passed the internal completeness check, meaning that eligible applications in Uganda exceeded available funding under the call by 2.3 times.
Based on the positive response and the quality of the response, Sida assesses that this confirms the utility and potential of the RBF model.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
